data.stimulus: In this video, Sean tells you what students can expect from academic discussions.
After listening, read the statements below. According to the video, are they TRUE or FALSE?
data.template:
1. Discussions and seminars are always led by tutors. {{response}}

  2.  Academic discussions are usually based on reading and research. {{response}}

  3.  Developing your language skills is important in helping you express your ideas clearly. {{response}}

  4.  During the PSE you will only practice participating in academic discussions. {{response}}

  5.  The purpose of today's online lesson is to help you participate effectively in seminars. {{response}}

data.stimulus:
Considering Different Perspectives

► In today's lesson we talked about considering different perspectives on a subject.

     

 

► Let's recap and look at another example. Read the statement below:

 

"A seriously disruptive child should be permanently excluded from school."

  • What do you think are the perspectives of the different people involved?

  • Would they probably be for or against?

Useful Language

Here are some useful phrases that can be used to talk about different perspectives.

► Order the words into a correct sentence

options.label: they would probably be concerned about the effect of the child’s behaviour on other children.
they would probably be concerned about their safety.
they would probably be concerned about it might negatively affect the child's grades.

data.stimulus:
Get Ready to Listen

Listen to a student comparing different perspectives on the previous statement.

 

► "A seriously disruptive child should be permanently excluded from school."

 

► What reasons does the speaker provide to support his claim?

 

1. The teacher of the child would probably want the child excluded from school because....

options.label: they may believe that excluding the child is not a severe punishment.
they may believe that it is the teacher’s and school’s responsibility to deal with the child’s behaviour problems.
they may not want to deal with the child’s behaviour problems.

data.stimulus: 2. The parents would probably want the child to remain at school because...

options.label: they might believe that reputation of the school might be damaged by excluding the child.
they believe that excluding the child might cause more problems for the school.
they may not want to deal with complaints from the child's parents

data.stimulus: 3. The headteacher would probably want the child to remain at school because...

options.label: they believe that we need to understand and deal with the cause of the child’s bad behaviour.
they believe that excluding the child is not a severe punishment.
they believe that excluding the child might damage the relationship with their classmates.

data.stimulus: 4. The child psychologist would probably want the child to remain at school because...

Below is a summary of the chairperson's responsibilities.









► Complete the summary using one choice from the drop down.
data.template: The purpose of a chairperson is to ensure that the participants of a meeting {{response}}, respect each other and respect the rules of the meeting. The chairperson starts the meeting, {{response}} everyone and states what the topic is. They must {{response}} the time, introducing each section of the agenda as they move through it, making sure there is {{response}} to discuss each {{response}}.

The chairperson should allow all those attending the meeting to have a chance to express their {{response}}. They should be {{response}} and encourage those present to {{response}} during the meeting and make all members feel welcomed and valued. The chair also has an important role encouraging {{response}} members to {{response}}.

data.stimulus:
Here is some useful language for chairing a discussion...

 

► Add the phrases below to the table.
data.template:
Getting started 
Managing contributions 
  •  Today, we’re looking {{response}}...
  •  Shall {{response}}?
  •  Who {{response}}?
  • Thanks {{response}}.
  • I think that’s all, {{response}} to the next subtopic?
Clarification 
Inviting people to contribute 
  • So, {{response}}...
  • Could you {{response}}?
  • David, would you {{response}}?
  • Would anyone {{response}}?

data.stimulus:
In the last part of this lesson, we will look at summarising the discussion.

► Listen to a student summarising the discussion from the beginning of the lesson.
data.template:
1. Complete the spaces with the exact words you hear.

This is a difficult question, but {{response}} agreed that such a child should be excluded from school, as this would be in the best interests of most people concerned. 

It's {{response}} this action might cause some damage to the child’s long-term ability to socialize effectively with other children, so we also agreed that {{response}} should only {{response}} if there is no other solution – I mean, if all else fails.

 

Check your spelling carefully!

data.stimulus: The text below explains why summarising is important and gives some useful tips and advice.
data.template:
Summarising is extremely important to the success of your communication with others, particularly in {{response}}. 

Why is summarizing important? 

You summarize to:

  • Note any special and {{response}} from the conversation that you feel need to be highlighted
  • Bring the discussion to a close
  • Refresh each other’s memory of what has been discussed

What's in a summary?

It is vital when summarizing that you are as {{response}} as possible. Don't repeat the entire conversation all over again!

However, there are 3 ELEMENTS that a summary MUST contain:

  • Important {{response}} obtained from the discussion.
  • Important {{response}} given by the participants.
  • Any {{response}} made by the group.

How to summarise:

► Here's a summarizing {{response}} to make it easy!

  1. STEP ONE: Introduce the summary. In other words, {{response}} you are going to summarize the discussion. For example, you could say: “So, let's just review what we have discussed today."
  2. STEP TWO: {{response}} (say again) the main points (ONLY!). Keep your summary to the point and don't add {{response}}. Only mention those things that are {{response}} and necessary and make sure you include the 3 ELEMENTS that must be included in a summary, i.e. Facts, Contributions and Decisions.
  3. STEP THREE: Thank the rest of the group for {{response}} in the discussion.
